arch:property.oc:show_val: 0.38 m in diameter. The stone is positioned so it is 3.26 m from either the west or east wall of the cavea where the chord would be the diameter of a circle. The south point on the cavea wall is 3.10 m from the center pivot.

Phase V: Late Nabataean CE 1st c. redesign and repairs, including the addition of the Theater, intercolumnar walls, Central Arch and platform, East and West Interior Staircases and landings, East and West Vaulted Chambers, and the East and West Rear Staircases. Limestone pavement is laid on all new floor areas.
In the center of the sondage.

A reused smaller column drum placed as a guide for the laying out of the Orchestra wall and the associated architecture of the Theatron. The column drum provides a central pivot for the construction of the horseshoe-shaped wall. The stone itself is slightly tipped to the southeast and has been packed into place or supported by Locus 9. The column drum has a fine white stucco adhering to it. And is likely part of the same decoration as the two architectural fragments from Locus 7.
